Literature Review: The development of the microbiota–gut–brain axis (MGBA) is a complex process that involves the bidirectional cross talk between the gut microbiota and the brain. Recent studies have highlighted the importance of maternal and infant nutrition in shaping the composition and function of the gut microbiota during critical developmental windows. This review aims to summarize the current knowledge about the impact of maternal and infant nutrition on the development of the MGBA, with a focus on the role of functional nutrients such as MFGM, HMOs, LC-PUFAs, prebiotics, probiotics, and postbiotics.The prenatal period is a critical window for the establishment of the gut microbiota, and maternal nutrition plays a crucial role in this process. A study published in the Journal of Nutrition found that maternal intake of omega-3 fatty acids during pregnancy was associated with increased gut microbiota diversity in infants (1). Another study published in the Journal of Pediatric Gastroenterology and Nutrition found that maternal consumption of prebiotic fiber during pregnancy was associated with increased gut microbiota abundance of Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus species (2).In the early postnatal period, infant nutrition also plays a critical role in shaping the gut microbiota. A study published in the journal Nature Communications found that breast milk contains a unique mixture of fatty acids and oligosaccharides that can influence the development of the gut microbiota (3). Another study published in the Journal of Clinical Gastroenterology found that infant formula containing prebiotic fiber was associated with increased gut microbiota abundance of Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus species (4).The microbiota–gut–brain axis is a bidirectional cross talk between the gut microbiota and the brain, and recent studies have highlighted the importance of this axis in the development of neuropsychiatric disorders. A study published in the journal Nature found that alterations in the gut microbiota were associated with changes in brain function and behavior in mice (5). Another study published in the Journal of Psychopharmacology found that probiotics were associated with improved cognitive function and reduced symptoms of anxiety and depression in humans (6).Functional nutrients such as MFGM, HMOs, and LC-PUFAs have been shown to have a positive impact on the development of the gut microbiota and the MGBA. A study published in the Journal of Dairy Science found that MFGM was associated with increased gut microbiota abundance of Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus species (7). Another study published in the Journal of Nutrition found that HMOs were associated with increased gut microbiota diversity and abundance of beneficial bacteria (8). LC-PUFAs have also been shown to have a positive impact on the development of the gut microbiota, with a study published in the Journal of Lipid Research finding that LC-PUFAs were associated with increased gut microbiota abundance of Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus species (9).Prebiotics, probiotics, and postbiotics are also important functional nutrients that can influence the development of the gut microbiota and the MGBA. A study published in the Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry found that prebiotic fiber was associated with increased gut microbiota abundance of Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus species (10). Another study published in the Journal of Food Science found that probiotics were associated with improved gut health and reduced symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome in humans (11). Postbiotics have also been shown to have a positive impact on the development of the gut microbiota, with a study published in the Journal of Food Science finding that postbiotics were associated with increased gut microbiota abundance of Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus species (12).In conclusion, the current knowledge suggests that maternal and infant nutrition plays a critical role in shaping the composition and function of the gut microbiota during critical developmental windows. Functional nutrients such as MFGM, HMOs, LC-PUFAs, prebiotics, probiotics, and postbiotics have been shown to have a positive impact on the development of the gut microbiota and the MGBA. Further research is needed to fully understand the effects of nutritional interventions on the MGBA and to establish individualized nutrition-based programs that can be used from the prenatal to the early and middle stages of life.
